newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia, Belarus agree on union referendums - agency.
newsitem.headline: Russia, Belarus agree on union referendums - agency.

text.p: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and Belarus leader Alexander Lukashenko have agreed in principle to hold simultaneous national referendums on closer integration between their countries, Interfax news agency said on Saturday.
It quoted sources close to Yeltsin as saying he would touch on the issue in a speech to the Russian parliament next Thursday, but gave no details and did not give a date for the referendums.
Yeltsin raised the idea of holding referendums on closer integration between the two former Soviet republics in January in a letter to Lukashenko, who welcomed the suggestion.
"The presidents of Russia and Belarus, Boris Yeltsin and Alexander Lukashenko, have decided in principle on holding simultaneous nationwide referendums on integration," Interfax said.
It said Yeltsin, demanding more resolute moves, believed a state of "semi-unification" was more expensive than the cost of fuller political and economic integration.
Yeltsin and Lukashenko signed a pact last year on creating a "community" between the two Slav states but few moves have been made towards closer integration.

Yeltsin's letter to Lukashenko in January raised the possibility of Russia and its small western neigbour of 10 million people having one government with a single budget and currency taxation laws and united fuel and energy systems.
Calls for re-integration with former Soviet republics are supported by many Russians.

Closer integration with Belarus is widely seen as a rebuff to NATO's plans to offer membership to countries of eastern and central Europe, although the Kremlin denies this is the intention in seeking closer ties.
